Psychology student here! While “antisocial” is the technically correct term, I think it carries more stigma than the terms “psychopath” or “sociopath” do, and I really dislike it. Saying “antisocial” just makes it sound like you’re introverted or don’t like to interact with people, thus minimizing the weight the term for a serious personality disorder has. I get that “psychopath/sociopath” tends to make people think of twisted serial killers or something, but even that is more accurate than the term “antisocial.” They should have used a different term when renaming this disorder. Honestly, the entire system of the way we name and classify disorders in psychology is so broken and stupid. I’m still salty that they god rid of Asperger’s Syndrome and merged it into Autism Spectrum Disorder in the DSM-V, but that’s a story for another time.

One of my personal theories about mental disorders/ illnesses that I feel is important to mention is- everyone has symptoms of any and all disorders. They only become diagnosed as a disorder or illness when it starts to inhibit normal functions. I am diagnosed with anxiety and depression, these impede my ability to function, however my very obvious ADHD does not effect my functioning “to much,” so I haven’t searched for a formal diagnoses. Everyone is a little depressed, anxious,  or dependent, but it’s when the symptoms effect functioning that it becomes a disorder.

Another interesting thing about BPD vs ASPD...
A common misconception is that people with ASPD are able to read other people’s body language very well and figure out their emotions/what they’re thinking. This is a myth for those with ASPD, but it’s true for those with BPD.
People with ASPD lack the ability to form bonds, and therefore lack the ability to feel empathy. In order to read body language, we use the region of the brain responsible for bond-forming and empathy. People with ASPD have a difficult time reading social cues, and instead will observe your behaviors and actions before deciding how to react to you. People with BPD, despite having lower responses to empathy, have a unique condition known as borderline empathy. Those with BPD are able to read the emotions and body language of others more precisely than the non-BPD population, especially to a highly specific extent. People with BPD can easily assort through the emotions of neutral faces, whereas the non-BPD population struggles to do so.

Both BPD and ASPD have genetic components that are believed to be brought out through trauma and neglect.
There is a gene known to cause road rage known as the Warrior gene that is believed to play a role in antisocial traits.

And women are more likely to be labeled as having BPD, whereas they might have another condition such as bipolar, ADHD, PTSD, or even something neurological like autism (which is severely under diagnosed in females). They will often simply label a female patient as having BPD since they might be considered difficult and no one wants to deal with them.

These online tests aren't able to diagnose a personality disorder as many think. You need a trained professional to observe you and interact with you as well. For example, the "Dark Triad" tests show that I score under average in Psycopathy and Narcissism but rather high in Machiavellianism. This is mostly because I'm very introverted and had significant social anxiety as a teen, and thus manipulated situations to my advantage to avoid uncomfortable situations, and have become quite adept at it over the years. Due to this experience, the web of lies I can spin, if I wanted to (and have in some emergency situations), is quite significant because my memory is great and I have developed techniques to make the lies believable and consistent with different people.
However, I'm also a bit of a moralist and believe strongly in treating others right and fairly, and not manipulating them for my own gain at their expense - a treating others the way I want to be treated thing. This has many of the traits of being a personality disorder, but isn't "good enough" to diagnose me with an actual personality disorder.
So my point being, you can't' really diagnose yourself with these disorders just from a test. :)

Empathy is NOT sympathy or compassion. All the absence of empathy entails is a disconnect between your emotions and someone else's. You don't necessarily understand why or what other people feel! But that has no relation in your compassion or morals. Most statistics relating to aspd are nonsence because so few people can keep their preconceptions in control... It even agree on what the diagnosis is.

Anyway criminality has no relation to the disorder. All violent criminals will learn to reduce empathy and such as part of their experience. Also most aspd patients don't have conduct disorder because most of them don't get caught or simply aren't diagnosed or even don't engage in illegal activities instead displaying their lack of ability to learn from consequences and lack of impulse control elsewhere.

The disorder is likely the least understood because there's so much psuedo science relating to it. If anything the real disorder is only tertiary to the mythos of the psuchopath, and it's pure coincidence that such a disorder exists at all, considering there was no real psychology involved with the proposed idea of a sociopath originally.

In truth neurotypicals are desperate to separate themselves categorically from violent criminals so they made up a disorder, and their made up disorder has little relationship with the real deal.

Some real info on aspd: they don't learn from consequences because they were raised in an environment where consequences were inconsistent and unavoidable. Their parents moods would change and with it so would the rules. One day something is encouraged, the next its punished without warning. As for impulse control, the chaos and instability they're raised in creates an environment where they can't predict the future or plan ahead. Anything they save for is liable to be taken away, and they're generally kept miserable at all times. This makes them want to focus entirely on the now, without planning ahead, because that isn't an option in their home life. Then these thoughts and behaviors become rooted deeply j to their psychy and are almost impossible to unlearn.

And above all else, the empathy. I cannot stress enough how unnecessary this is. We can't empathize because the people who raised us fakes emotions in order to manipulate and control us. There was no rhyme or reason to their feelings, so there was no way to understand. Then we were often punished for our own emotions, and exposed to extremely distressing situations and material often enough to desensitize us. Nonetheless, anyone with aspd can understand how you feel if you use your words. We're not masters of manipulation, we just have to learn the social ques and such consciously because it's not intuitive to us. We don't hide our disorder in order to manipulate people, we do it to avoid your prejudice towards us, because we're instantly dehumanized and assumed an enemy once it's known.

These videos are so well done and so informative. I appreciate all the knowledge in them and understand there's an enormous amount of things to cover in such a small time; however the visual representations and verbal cues concerning these people who struggle with these disorders is somewhat dehumanizing.
Yes, there have been terrible, horrible people who have done atrocious things as a result of their PD, among other things, but the way people with PD's are depicted in this video, and the "examples" of people who have them (ie Breaking bad, ect) gives the impression that anyone who struggles with a PD are extreme, volatile individuals, spurring on what already is a large stigma against the people trying to find balance, health and recovery as they deal with these mental hurdles, and that's already hard enough.
These disorders are so complex and we are still in the dark about a great deal of what causes them and how they affect people. It doesn't help Hollywood has repeatedly used these disorders to turn people into absolute monsters (literally sometimes) on the big screen and in series. I wish there had been even ten seconds to acknowledge that the sweeping majority of these people are just that, people, and many are doing their absolute best to heal and progress.

A lot of psychiatric diagnosis is just a part of normal psychiatric (human) growth and imperfection. ( NPD, sociopathy and psychopathy are normally people in positions of power within a group or organisation. These people abuse power. These are the only ones who deserve a label. )

People on the lower spectrum have suffered at the hands of abuse of power. Narcissism and codependency is a POWER STRUGGLE within yourself. That means you struggle with BOTH. You are not one or the other. (So sometimes you're the bird and sometimes your the windscreen.) Their is a swinging of the pendulum dependent on the situation. Most people refuse to acknowledge their own dark side or flaws and pretend to only be on one side. Usually everyone else is the narcissist. They have issues with self empowerment because they have seen abuse of power.

Those that abuse power LOVE power more than they love LOVE. That's why they are incurable because their love of power (control (overt) /manipulation(covert) is what they need to feel alive. These people are destructive. Standing your ground against these antagonists may look like control but is a necessity. The ones who are stuck in dysfunctional cycles, normally have had no support and have experienced abuse ( either mental, emotional, spiritual and physical or all ) most of their lives. These people just need healing and can transition back to a balanced state. They just don't have the right model which is what they are subconsciously searching for. But keep ending up in the same dynamics. Until they understand that the way that they grew up was wrong they probably will continue to form these same relationships. Over and over again. So they actually are the victim. And telling them they are playing the victim is REDUNDANT!

I also don't agree that emotional detachment is a sign of these labels. They are emotionally "Disconnected" from reality. Because of what happened to them. Most of them suffer from PTSD (whether they are on the narc or codependent side of the spectrum) Detachment is healthy. Staying connected to the emotional energy of unhealthy people IS unhealthy. Your mental and emotional health should always be first priority. Leaving or cutting people off does not make you the narcissist. End the cycle with you.

i have BPD, and go to DBT, which is a specialized therapy for it, and i just wanted to explain it a little further.
BPD is caused by biology and your environment- you have a chemical imbalance, but you also had an invalidating environment growing up.
BPD, to me, means that your moods are significantly more intense, and you are also way more ‘sensitive’ to these emotions. It’s like, you and a friend are drinking coffee- to you, it’s scalding, but to your friend, it’s lukeworm. that’s how you interpret your emotions. because these emotions are so intense, a criteria for diagnosis is self-harming behaviors- cutting, burning, substance abuse- to attempt to cope with these emotions. bpd can’t truly be medicated, because it is very much in the way that you react— i take mood stabilizers to help with the BPD, but it only goes so far.

...Eh...sociopathy is really more of a characteristic, as opposed to a disorder, in and of itself; sociopathy can appear in ASPD, NPD, BPD, and I've even detected it in a person with HPD. And sociopathy is different from psychopathy, even though some mental health professionals use them, interchangeably. Sociopathy is nurture, and psychopathy is nature; a professor did in-depth research on the two, and found that psychopathy happens when the fetal brain in bathed in serotonin...sociopaths, on the other hand, simply default their 'empathy switch' to the 'off' position.

Research these things (especially the empathy switch) if you want to know more about this, as many people are misinformed.
(And yes, I did go to both undergraduate AND graduate school for psychology and counseling)

I have ASPD, and other than accidentally hurting my husband's feelings sometimes, I'm improving a hell of a lot. My dad had ASPD too, and I had a hell of a time juggling traumatic incidence over traumatic incidence as a child. I was an.......evil child. I was almost incarcerated and was horribly abusive to anyone I deemed unworthy of my presence.

When I was around 15 or so, I was diagnosed AGAIN with ASPD and PTSD. Unlike most, I realized I had a problem when I was thinking about killing animals. I looked online and found a religion I stuck to like glue. With meditation and this religion on my side, I got A LOT better. My PTSD is a raging mess right now because I haven't resolved my trauma yet, but I am not the little monster I once was.

Because of this, I "learned" most of the usual emotions (some I already naturally had like love, which is rare) so now I have a switch I can use when something serious is going on. I can "turn off" panic and anxiety during a social situation and get things done. I find it really useful. I also learned how to sympathize and look for body language that indicates people's feelings, this is entirely because I have a patient and loving husband.

I have no idea why I think I should be commenting this, but I hope this helps show that people with ASPD are treatable if they are willing to be treated.

I realized shortly after trying to diagnose my current bf that it isn't fair to label under something negative. we all go through times in our lives where any combination of these traits will show up or have already shown up or currently are showing in us....sometimes long term. it's less about genetics and more about what parts of our brains get nurtured and how and by who, our life experiences, upbringing childhood influences. anyway, every person in the world could be categorized using these personality disorders to label them, and they'd probably run through each label and fall into a new category, but always in at least one, possibly one prominent for life, but that doesn't mean the other symptoms aren't there. all these diagnosis do is tell ppl that there is something wrong with them, they now have an excuse for their behavior to justify the way they act and have little responsibility. so, the point is, psychological or mental health diagnosis limit us to a label that will be used to define us. we are no longer ever-changing, always learning and growing ppl, we are a narcissist or a sociopath or a schizoid and then this label defines our life, we become depended on this, like zombies, can't think for ourselves, only what we're told, we're programmed to mask our problems with lies and medications which may cause more damage and worse problems in the long. it is a vicious cycle to make us believe our lives depend on the very thing that is depended on us to survive and thrive. we have all been given a very corrupt illusion of happiness, go chase it, it's selfish, be the best and have the most, but it'll never be enough. you think you need this kind of diagnosis to your mind? minds were never intended to be exactly the same. we aren't robots, yet if we don't follow the superficial program, we get reprogrammed to do so

really educational, I like it

My own low levels of empathy kinda bother me. Like, I don't feel sad when my friends are sad... it feels like it doesn't have anything to do with me. I don't worry about them... I mean, I'm great at understanding their feelings, why they feel that way, their thought processes, how their personalities and experiences inform all that... There's just not much of an emotional connection. There's a little, like, I have felt shocked when someone told me she broke up with her boyfriend. I also have a strong shame and guilt reaction, even when it's not logical. In fact, when I empathize with others the most is when I've hurt them in some way, even by accident. I think my high level of responsibility contributes to that, and I think there's a strong genetic component, because my mother was the same way. Also, I care a lot about myself, and those with anti-social personality disorder don't (this complicates things, because not only do they not care if they hurt people, they don't care about the consequences to themselves).

It's true that I only started having good friends in college, and now that that's over, I feel I mostly just have acquaintances again... I wonder if it would be different if I'd had the same friends for years and years? I definitely had empathy for my dad, who I was close with... Sometimes I wonder if maybe not having friends growing up kinda broke me as far as developing empathy. That's probably unrealistic, but... It bothers me, because I worry that I'm missing out on the most wonderful thing in life. Like, I get SO invested in relationships between certain fictional characters (I admit it, I'm an obsessive shipper) (and yeah, I do tend to get more attached to characters, but that's because knowing their interiority, the projection involved, makes it easier for me to internalize them), and... It's like having it and not having, like knowing what I'm missing out on. I think it's a problem writers frequently deal with.

I'm probably worried about nothing; mental health professionals I've seen for anxiety seem to think so. But it still bothers me. Well, anyway, I definitely don't have anti-social personality disoder. This got long and rambling, but... I guess I'm just venting.

I first spotted signs of avoidant in me at around 16 years old. I ended up brushing it off then and tried getting on with my life. 6 and a half years later and after a lot of social jettisoning and generally not pursuing relationships, ever, i was approached by someone who wanted to test the waters of a relationship with me. boom, it came right back to me and again, and looking back at the years between i had clearly and consistently displayed those symptoms.
so the setting is like, beginning of last year i was hospitalised after heavy drinking and deep cuts, my crisis team referral did nothing. i was discharged without assessment. mid last year, saw a private psychiatrist. he had his own ideas about what was wrong, picked up on my unwillingness to engage in casual sex for relationship building, and recommended psychosexual counselling. late last year, crisis team referral after heavy drinking and self harm again. this time i was "assessed" by psychiatrists... who did nothing.
I suspect personality disorders but i'm not going to go in there and say "hey, i think i have this and that or such and such". that skews the assessment and introduces human error. so when i saw the top consultant psychiatrist in the unit i handed her a list of 9 different tools available to psychiatrists for assessment... she hadn't heard of a single one. i was fucking shocked to say the least. here's the list.
Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (MCMI)
Coolidge Axis II Inventory + / Coolidge Assessment Battery (CATI+ / CAB)
Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI)
Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI)
International Diagnostic Checklists (IDCL / IDCL-P)
Structured Clinical Interview for DSM Disorders (SCID)
ICD-10 Symptom Checklist for Mental Disorders
International Personality Disorder Examination (IPDE)
Lists of Integrated Criteria for Evaluation and Taxonomy in Depression (LICET-D)
But no, see, psychiatrists are quacks who would rather engage in unscientific woo and fluff, and think that them taking a history and making a stab in the dark with their own opinions is more productive and patient-centered than using any of the above.
Meanwhile, I had downloaded the IPDE and decided to go through it myself for a laugh. Multiple times I found myself trying to explain away the positive scoring for Anankastic (Obsessive-Compulsive). But the further along I went, the more it dawned on me that that could actually be a thing for me, and then it all fell into place. It not only explained me, my excessive need to plan ahead, and my conduct in workplaces where I would shout up the chain of command if I didn't think my superiors were pulling their weight, or stole peoples' jobs when I could do a better, more thorough and consistent job than them (My former manager still says after 2 and a half years that he still hasn't found anyone with my work ethic even though there were certain "personality clashes" that came with it). It also explains my parents. Both workaholics who need to do their job a certain way. My dad, who I once worked for, is a very astute businessman, who pulled together a fantastic team of people who gave me far too high an expectation for workplaces at the beginning of my working life. A man who takes measure twice cut once to extremes. A guy who uses jigs, frames, set squares, spirit levels and postcrete to construct industrial-duty raised beds in his own garden. And my mum, a GP who overstretches herself in working hours simply because she refuses to treat patients as if they're on a conveyor belt. They're also both neurotic and passive-aggressive to the hilt. But yeah, bottom line is the anankastic was so ego-syntonic for me that I didn't even notice it and honestly still feel justified in calling out every single incompetent fucking jobsworth I have to come in contact with on their bullshit, and for not working to MY exacting standards... I just wish psychiatrists would do their job right so I could actually get diagnosed and move on with my life!

I understand why people get so angry that young people self-diagnose themselves with mental illness. I am self-diagnosed with Borderline Personality Disorder, but I've been researching the illness for over three years now and have been studying abnormal psychology as a whole for even longer. I've been taking psychology classes, and from talking with my teachers, they seem to believe what I'm saying and are concerned about me. I've been thinking very scientifically and logically about it, and not jumping to conclusions just to get sympathy. Borderline Personality Disorder apparently runs in my family on my paternal side, so I don't understand why my parents refuse to believe that mental illness is real at all. That is the reason why I am not officially diagnosed yet, and all I really want to do is better myself.
I just wish people, especially young teenagers with very little experience, would stop diagnosing themselves with BPD. It's insulting to me, especially because I am unable to go to a psychiatrist because my parents are afraid will reflect poorly upon their parenting. You make me lose credibility, and you also make others who have been diagnosed with it look really bad. It's ridiculous. My friend's 14-year-old sister will probably proudly announce she has BPD any day now, and she'll be showered in the sympathy and attention that she desires. She doesn't understand the degrees of guilt, self-hatred and anger that the illness entails. It makes me sick.

My 16 year old daughter has a clinical diagnosis of Antisocial Personality Disorder. She was diagnosed with Conduct Disorder at the age of two. And it's the hardest thing I've ever had to deal with. While I don't claim to have been the perfect mother,  she was never abused or neglected... She was always loved and cared for by a large extended family. She has also always had access to professional mental health care,  but no one seems to be able to help her. I live in constant fear of the woman she will become as she had no conscious or empathy nor any respect for authority or social norms.  I am fearful of her and for her and I deal with my failure as a mother every single day. What did I do wrong? I did everything the psychologist,  psychiatrist and therapist told me to do. I loved her,  I gave her attention, I gave her opportunities and privileges,  yet I also set boundaries and appropriate consequences for behaviors,  both positive and negative.

I think it's worth remembering that, while there is a correlation between childhood trauma and BPD, actual causation is still debated. Not all BPD patients were abused or neglected. Also the idea that it's a simply "learned" condition is pretty off. It's been shown that genetics do actually play a role in development of BPD.

A disorder isn't something anyone would want to have in their life. When one is diagnosed with a disorder, it makes living your everyday life extremely difficult. 

Whether the person is ego-dystonic or ego-syntonic, a disorder is not something to be taken lightly or fantasizes to have.

As one of the lucky few who manage to have antisocial personality disorder without completely losing all ability to function in society, I feel like some curious people may like to hear my findings and perspective. Or not.

This is going to be a long comment. It will probably sound like something straight out of a psychology publication but without any formal knowledge of psychology. These are just the things that I've found out during my attempts to understand my "condition." Regardless of the likely invalidity of everything that follows, all of this has helped me understand how to deal with my ASPD and possibly use it to better my life. To those who are still curious, read on.

Aside from those who devolve into common criminals, antisocial personality disorder creates as many opportunities in life as it destroys.

Oversimplified, people with ASPD lack two primary things: morality and empathy. From my admittedly limited understanding, morality is the ability to distinguish "right" from "wrong" in an emotional or empathic context whereas ethicality (if that term is correct) is the ability to comply with standards or rules of conduct - usually in a professional environment such as a school or hospital, but also in the sense of social conduct. Laws are an example of ethics - regardless of if they are "moral," they must be obeyed or consequences can occur.

In an attempt to demonstrate the difference between morality and ethicality, imagine this scenario. You are a nurse. A terminally ill cancer patient is near the end of his or her life, and is in immense pain. He or she pleads for you to simply end it for them. Some may view doing so on his or her request to be the moral action to take, others may not. However, the undoubted ethical action to take would be to decline the patient's request.

Some people with ASPD, while incapable of morality (the term for this is "amoral" as in without morality - rather than "immoral" as in against morality) are still capable of ethicality. While I am by no means a professional, I suspect that the reason is because morality requires a conscious decision to me made using one's empathy as the criteria for judgement. Those with ASPD don't have empathy, or perhaps have a severely limited form of it if they are lucky.

Ethics, however, are often outlined in a code of conduct. In the case of socially ethical conduct, where a code of conduct is not really present, the conduct can be observed and learned through trial and error. Ethics can be learned whereas morals cannot. The presence of morality may greatly assist the development of ethicality, but it is not required.

So, those with ASPD lack morality and empathy. The lack of empathy is likely the cause for the lack of morality. Furthermore, it can be reasoned that the lack of morality can potentially hinder the growth of ethicality. A lack of ethicality leads to the disorderly, potentially dangerous behaviors associated with ASPD. Therefore, if this is correct, the lack of empathy is the cause of the disorder, or at least it is the primary cause. 

Everything to do with ASPD seems to revolve around lack of empathy. So what is empathy?

Empathy is the ability to understand and share the feelings of another. That's what a quick Google search says. This is the part where my case of ASPD stops being a hindrance in my personal research/musing and starts becoming an information source that most don't have access to.

I'd like to assert that there are two variations of empathy: natural and artificial.

Natural empathy is the ability that most people have to immediately and effortlessly recognize and respond to the emotions of others. It takes place subconsciously. This is the thing that nobody with ASPD has access to.

Artificial empathy is still the ability to recognize and respond to the emotions of others - but not automatically and not without effort. It takes place consciously. You can call it artificial empathy, pseudoempathy, emulated empathy, or anything to that effect.

Imagine that emotions are math problems and empathy is the set of operations needed to solve them.

Natural empathy is like a calculator; you punch in the numbers and get the result.

Artificial empathy is like solving the math problems by hand. The entire emotional equation has to be analyzed and variables - facial expression, body language, breathing patterns, tone of voice, perspiration levels, eye contact, and more - need to be accounted for. All of the operations have to be performed manually.

Both forms of empathy get the same result, but artificial empathy takes longer and has much more room for error.

Why is this important? Because with training, people with ASPD can learn to perform artificial empathy.

With this, those with ASPD can function in society. They can maintain personal relationships and such. However, it is incredibly difficult.

In my experience, just so much as having a simple conversation can be mentally exhausting - at least when it comes to talking to people I don't know well. You see, there are subtle differences in the way we all express emotion. Natural empathy isn't fooled by these subtle differences, but artificial empathy certainly is. The more you get to know somebody, the more familiar those differences become. There are some people who I know very well. With these people, I feel as if my artificial empathy can rival natural empathy. However, with absolute strangers, I'm a train wreck. I once attended one of my college's social events. I ended up leaving within half an hour with an intense headache - induced by the mental stress caused by using artificial empathy constantly on multiple complete strangers.

As with the "emotional calculator" example I gave, solving difficult equations constantly while trying to participate in conversation is not the most pleasant of experiences.

While learning how to emulate empathy can allow a person with ASPD to function in society, there will always be limits.

But speaking of limits, empathy is not only a tool; it is also a limiter.

Often, empathy can cause one to overlook things. Morals are, by nature, subjective. They vary between societies, between people, and even between situations. As empathy - and by extension, morals - can have a massive effect on decision-making, there are some decision-making situations that may be better off without the subjectivity that morals introduce. Indeed, decisions that require objectivity are potentially best suited for somebody with ASPD. "Needs of the Many vs Needs of the Few" situations are often best handled without morality limiting the options that one considers. In fact, morals may prevent one from paying any attention to the solution that just may be best for everyone.

A lack of morality can potentially lead to a more objective worldview as well. Instead of getting caught up with "right" and "wrong," people without empathy can focus more on looking at the world for what it really is. As for what the world really is, it isn't really my place to say here.

So yeah. Sorry for the wall of text. I just figured that if I can indulge just one person's curiosity, typing all of this out would be worth it.

I feel like you missed a big part of what BPD is about. People with BPD feel emotions more easily, more deeply, and for longer than others do. When their brains are scanned, hyperactivity is shown in the insula—which helps determine how intensely we experience negative emotions. Also, regions in the frontal part of the brain—which are thought to help us control our emotional reactions—are underactive. So, although part of it can be caused by harmful or neglectful environments, it's important to remember that someone with BPD has a brain that is actually malfunctioning. It's not all about the "nurture" (reference to the nature nurture debate in psychology).

I thought at first it was Bipolar disorder, because that is what my mother is diagnosed with, but I read that severe mood swings are more often caused by a trigger in BPD, but not in Bipolar disorder. Great video as always, but the way you're pronouncing "psychopathy" is driving me nuts. It's "sigh-KOP-uh-thee," not "sigh-coh-PATH-ee."

Psychopathy is not an out-of-vogue term. It's not listed as a mental disorder anymore, but it does not equate 1-1 to antisocial personality disorder. They are similar ideas, but people who rate highly on the PCL-R do not necessarily also fit the diagnosis of ASPD, and vice versa.

The PCL-R and PCL-YV are still very commonly used, but labelling people as "psychopaths" is highly discouraged because of the stigma. For example, if someone is labelled as a psychopath, many people might interpret that as meaning that the person cannot benefit from intervention programs, and therefore due to funding, the person in question might not be offered these options. Particularly with youths, this can serve as a self-fullfilling prophecy, as more research is needed to determine the pervasiveness of psychopathic traits in youths; they may reap more benefits from such intervention than adults. Multiple assessment measures should always be used in determining sentencing and intervention, not just the PCL.

Source: I'm a research assistant with the government, and assess violent young offenders on the PCL-YV, among other assessments. :) Also, I dunno if it's just regional dialects or what, but I have never heard it pronounced PSYcho-pathy. We pronounce it psy-CHO-pathy!

What makes psychological disorders more than wild speculations?
Is there any non-theoretical scientifical basis for any of them?
There is neuroscientifical evidence for some theories. But psychology has no foundation to work on. In a way it is a charlatan science, since the human brain is now as well understood as the earth was in the 13th century.

Psychology always speaks as if a person "has" or "is" something. As if sociopathic thinking or behavior would indicate me "having a disorder" or me "being" someone called a "sociopath" rather than just taking the thoughts and actions for what they are. It infers - without any basis - that a person expressing the symptoms of what they call a disorder results in a state of that disorder.
A psychologist seems to be obsessed with the fact that a disorder is something similar to an illness, something that requires treatment.

But unlike a doctor seeking to cure a naturally malignant illness,
the psychologist seeks to artificially create the malignant state of disorder within the patient's personality in order to be able to cure it. Simply for self-preservation of the psychologists profession and not for the sake of helping the patient.
I hope people use this current video series less to self-diagnose, and more to understand those who are already suffering.

I never cut or raged out because of my BPD - but rather, I think my disorder (I've no idea 'cause I honestly don't understand it in myself) is based on my sensitivity to what's around me.  If there's any violence, or raised voices, or if I even THINK I'm in trouble - I freak out, and sometimes can have full triggering attacks that leave me disassociated or even suicidal because I can't think past the situation.  Going to movie theatres can trigger attacks because of the emotions caused by what I'm seeing feel a lot more "real" to me (so heartache, fear, or just plain embarrassment) and with other people there, I get self-conscious and feel the need to call for help and get out of there.  This doesn't happen at home because I have a lot of coping mechanisms to get me through it that I can't take to the theatre (like my dog - she's an ESA but not a working animal.)

Both my room mate and I have BPD and our symptoms are worlds apart - which makes it difficult to relate to each other, and other people because not a lot of people go through what I do.  We go to a program with other people with psychological disorders, but some consider us "normal" because our symptoms are often triggered, rather than a constant state.  It's very scary to have an 'episode', and then being told "it's just for attention" when we are genuinely terrified and trying our best to cope with the situation with whatever we can.  Neither of us cut or lash out - I tend to have anxiety attacks that often turn to suicidal thoughts and the feeling of worthlessness for not being able to deal with the situation in a normal way.  Now I have an ESA (emotional support animal) at home, that gives me purpose and keeps me calm when watching potentially intense movies, or dealing with social situations that I can take her (like the library, or going to the bank. I live in a small town so most places that don't serve food happily let her in).  I also have an amazing boyfriend who is aware of all three of my disorders (I also have Bipoloar and GAD - which are also being treated) and is always on call in some way if I need help.  It could be a phone call if he's working, or if he's not and I'm in a situation, he will come get me no questions asked.

The fact I now have a name for why my thoughts and behaviours were the way they are was a huge relief because I knew something else was wrong that wasn't from the Bipolar or GAD - but still makes me wonder if there is something wrong with me, or if I only think there is?  There's still not a lot known about the broad range of symptoms and behavioural problems that go with BPD and many other personality disorders, and makes things rather difficult and tricky to explain.  I do understand that a lot of these behaviours are caused from traumatic childhood abuse, and a lot of it was beyond my control as an child and adolescent and then in an abusive marriage which I left.  I've since healed from that, but still dealing with a lot of the self-abusive thought patterns (in pure suicidal thoughts and self-hatred) and inability to cope with stressful situations. 

I have learned a lot of coping mechanisms that do work for me though.  I taught myself to knit, I read Tarot, I take the dog on nature walks and around town, I listen to uplifting music, I don't go to theatres (okay not a coping mechanism, but sometimes avoiding things are necessary, besides I'd rather watch them at home anyways), I have a social worker, a therapist and a psychiatrist all working with me to help get me to a level where I can cope.  My episodes went from two or three times a month, down to once every... 6-10 months in about a year and a half.  Do they still happen?  Probably for the rest of my life - but at least now I know what to do.

Anyways, that's my story, and hopefully answers some questions people might have about different symptoms.  If not, just ignore me.  I just wanted to give some insight so people didn't think you needed to be a cutter or rage-machine to be diagnosed with BPD.

At the risk of sounding like an alarmist, I have a sneaking suspicion that modern media is playing a role in fostering anti-social behaviour. A lot of contemporary popular shows not just feature but are built entirely around cruelty, malice, violence and violation of other people. The intent, I surmise, is for these shows to sell themselves on the horror of doing the unthinkable like no show before has "dared" (false as that may be). The result, however, is a general desensitisation to anti-social behaviour and - worse - rationalisation and internalisation of such.

I, personally, am to the point where seeing rape, murder or torture in a show does not in me the correct response of revulsion that the show is clearly going for, but rather one of sighing resignation. "Seriously? Again? You're using cheap deaths in place of actual storytelling? I don't care about these people because I know they exist solely to die a shocking death. I am not shocked any more." Granted, fiction/reality disconnect prevents this feeling of melancholy towards suffering from applying to the real-world suffering of actual living people. But I can tell you for a fact that the impulse is already there.

I can't wait for this fad of character development through gritty violence to end, personally.

I have concerns with the concept of ASPD, at least as Hank describes it here -- it strikes me as boiling down to the stigmatization of "incorrect" emotions, those most subjective and private of human experiences. It doesn't help that not help that virtually nobody is self-diagnosed and there's no treatment; as such, it literally seems to have no function outside of lending the cover of science to (subjective) moral judgement.


*It should go without saying that the degree that actions (self-destructive and otherwise), not empathy, etc, are part of the diagnosis, I have less issue with it.

I recently wrote an essay on the different historiographical depictions and interpretations of Vlad Tepes. A study of a wider variety of contemporary sources from different ethnic and religious contexts shows that Vlad may not have been so bad as we in the west usually interpret him i.e. as a bloodthirsty tyrant probably suffering from Anti-Social Disorder. A lot of the more widespread sources we have which describe gory incidents such as the Brasov impalings definitely had motive to demonise Vlad for one reason or another, whether that be political, religious or social. Likewise, there are many contemporary sources which give justification for Vlad's acts as necessary or morally preferable, depictions which are equally susceptible to bias.

But when it comes to biological, psychological and social roots, Vlad has no lack of contextual causes. Considering that most of his family committed acts of murder and were in turn murdered, the fact that as a child he was literally sold to the enemy and there forced to watch executions, and how he was historically surrounded by similar violent characters such as Ivan the Terrible to the East and Sultan Mehmed the Conqueror to the South, not to mention Louis XI of France, Ferdinand of Naples, and Cesare Borgia of Italy...Vlad wasn't too different. Even the impaling was unoriginal.

So he may have had ASD. But there are many today who would disagree with that due to the history. Or lack thereof.

I have Borderline Personality Disorder, and it's a tough diagnosis to carry due to its stigma among professionals and laymen alike. On the other hand, I've been relieved to find many people rethinking how they view and approach it and creating new models of treatment. Personally, I've found DBT most effective. The skills that model puts forth, combined with the strong emphasis on validation, seem to work very well with both myself and others I've met. In my city, we have outpatient therapy options. I'm not sure what magical sorting hat they use in the office, but there are two basic programs: Adult Outpatient (AOP) and Intensive Outpatient (IOP). I was placed in IOP, and noticed nearly every single person in the program was Borderline, with a rare Cluster A or Antisocial patient in the mix. IOP, at least, strictly followed the DBT model, with classes on self-esteem or art therapy tossed in to round it out. It was pretty effective. I still keep my DBT papers lying around to read through when I need a refresher or guidance. 

I'm not going to paint a happy face on the disorder--Borderline patients can be manipulative and suicidal and angry and cruel and impulsive and extreme. They can also be some of the sweetest, most earnest, empathetic people you will ever meet. We operate in extremes, in black and white thinking, and frequently internalize and then project onto the nearest person who does wrong by us. Just being aware that we are doing this isn't enough, and finding a treatment model and team and sticking to it can be a challenge in an of itself. Luckily, I really believe there have  been huge strides in both understanding and treating BPD, and I'm hopeful it will only get better. It heartens me to see a video talking about it and other personality disorders on such a prolific channel. It's nice to get some objective exposure.

Last comment: There IS a difference between psychopathy and APD. APD shows a much more marked lack of desire to comply with societal norms, whereas psychopaths usually operate on those norms as manipulative tools. An antisoc might kill someone and set a home on fire for the fun of it, whereas a psychopath might threaten those things or even do them in order to gain an ulterior motive.

I have a big problem with the diagnosis of 'histrionic personality disorder' as it seems to be very much rooted in gendered ideas of how 'proper women' should and should not behave. The name kind of gives away its roots as one of the last vestiges of 'hysteria', meaning 'wandering uterus'. I read that many people believe histrionic personality disorder is simply a cluster of symptoms that are more likely to be expressed by women with narcissistic personality disorder, and as such shouldn't be a separate disorder. Something similar happens in the diagnosis of Autism, where women with autism are often diagnosed late as they present with slightly different symptoms, including less likelihood of antisocial behaviour and more socially accepted obsessions (collecting makeup or facts about celebrities instead of knowing everything about trains, for example). Really though, I think we still have a lot to learn in terms of mental disorders and we need to take our cultural and social biases into account before putting people into boxes.

It's still pretty tough sometimes to shut down a subconscious, pernicious tendency to narcissistic thoughts, and I still try to avoid the dread and utter boredom of social gatherings like the plague, but long gone are the times when I thought altruism was a burden of brain chemistry I was special enough to have gotten rid off.

So people with actual empathy, go grab your nearest socially awkward family member and be kind to them, because the undying desire for kindling and human love and care might not be felt in the same way by all, but it sure helps to make all lives better.
